body:
```
[1/1] Cythonizing giacpy/giacpy.pyx
/usr/lib64/python3.8/site-packages/Cython/Compiler/Main.py:344: FutureWarning: Cython directive 'language_level' not set, using '3str' for now (Py3). This has changed from earlier releases! File: /builddir/build/BUILD/giacpy-0.7.0/giacpy/giacpy.pxd
  tree = Parsing.p_module(s, pxd, full_module_name)
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "setup.py", line 129, in <module>
    ext_modules+=cythonize([Extension(
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.8/site-packages/Cython/Build/Dependencies.py", line 1105, in cythonize
    cythonize_one(*args)
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.8/site-packages/Cython/Build/Dependencies.py", line 1246, in cythonize_one
    result = compile_single(pyx_file, options, full_module_name=full_module_name)
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.8/site-packages/Cython/Compiler/Main.py", line 575, in compile_single

  File "/usr/lib64/python3.8/site-packages/Cython/Compiler/Main.py", line 503, in run_pipeline

  File "/usr/lib64/python3.8/site-packages/Cython/Compiler/Pipeline.py", line 356, in run_pipeline

  File "/usr/lib64/python3.8/site-packages/Cython/Compiler/Pipeline.py", line 336, in run

  File "/usr/lib64/python3.8/site-packages/Cython/Compiler/Pipeline.py", line 52, in generate_pyx_code_stage

  File "/usr/lib64/python3.8/site-packages/Cython/Compiler/ModuleNode.py", line 167, in process_implementation

  File "/usr/lib64/python3.8/site-packages/Cython/Compiler/ModuleNode.py", line 459, in generate_c_code

  File "/usr/lib64/python3.8/site-packages/Cython/Compiler/ModuleNode.py", line 2797, in generate_module_init_func

  File "/usr/lib64/python3.8/site-packages/Cython/Compiler/Nodes.py", line 403, in generate_execution_code
```

comment_data.body: I didn't know about the `property xxx:` syntax. Is it documented somewhere? The only documentation I see is for using it as a decorator: `@property`.

@Mattip https://cython.readthedocs.io/en/latest/src/userguide/extension_types.html#properties - it's an older syntax from before Cython supported decorator properties.

I'm not completely sure if it should be possible to have a function called `help` and a property called `help`, but it shouldn't crash.

It fails on the current 0.29.x branch. If I go back to 0.28.6 then it just returns the method (i.e. the property doesn't to have work)

```
>>> HelpClass().help
<built-in method help of prop.HelpClass object at 0x7f65b4a3be80>
```

What is the desired behaviour?
- silently allow a property and method to override eachother (like python), which is a change in behaviour between 0.28 and 3.0 and will result in unhappy faces from giacpy since they will get runtime recursion errors
- raise an error if a property has the same name as a class method/attribute when parsing
- easy way out: wrap line 2344 in `generate_assignment_code` with a `try`/`except` to call `error()` instead.
Or go back to 0.28 behaviour which seems to be "not override a method/attribute with a property"

Probably one of:

* silently allow a property and method to override eachother (like python), which is a change in behaviour between 0.28 and 3.0 and will result in unhappy faces from giacpy since they will get runtime recursion errors
* raise an error if a property has the same name as a class method/attribute when parsing

Most likely the latter (simply because it's easiest to do).

Personally I don't think the 0.28 behaviour was ever meaningfully correct, but it has the advantage of not changing things.

--------------

It looks like something that really needs to be fixed in giacpy though, even if Cython could handle it better too. Based on the simplified test they could probably just delete the property.

Both: cython should handle this better and giacpy needs a fix. I could not figure out how to register to file an issue at [giacpy](https://gitlab.math.univ-paris-diderot.fr/han/giacpy), so I sent an email to the owner. 

I am trying to write a failing test for this, but have run into a problem. Do the tests/error/test*.py tests actually run properly? Modifying the error message in a random error test, say `e_decorators.pyx`, and running `python runtests.py e_decorators` passes, even though the error messages now do not match. Modifying the code to not raise an error also passes the test run. Is this expected?

The author of giacpy has [fixed the source](https://gitlab.math.univ-paris-diderot.fr/han/giacpy/-/commit/223018904e80c5d839e1c727ce136d2886b55b2e) and I checked that was sufficient to allow cython to process the file.

> I am trying to write a failing test for this, but have run into a problem. Do the tests/error/test*.py tests actually run properly? Modifying the error message in a random error test, say `e_decorators.pyx`, and running `python runtests.py e_decorators` passes, even though the error messages now do not match. Modifying the code to not raise an error also passes the test run. Is this expected?

They do work in general, but `e_decorators.pyx` in particular looks broken. I'm not 100% sure but I think `_ERRORS` has to be the last thing in the file.

I am looking for the correct spot to "raise an error if a property decorator has the same name as a class method/attribute when parsing".  One strategy would be when visiting attributes/methods check for a decorator, and when visiting the decorator check attributes/methods. Is there something like a resolver pass in the ParseTreeTrasforms that would be a good place to do this? 

xref #3975 which fixed the `e_decorators.pyx` test.

I'd think it'd probably be when decorators are set up in [`AnalyseDeclarationsTransform`](https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/master/Cython/Compiler/ParseTreeTransforms.py#L1632) or possibly in `PropertyNode.analyse_expressions` (or `PropertyNode.analyse_declarations`). I'm guessing the difficulty would be that properties usually implemented in terms of a function of the same name, so you need to ignore that.
I tried something in #3984, but it is not correct. I am not sure I am on the right track.

This discussion is a bit theoretical now that giacpy has cleaned up the code causing this.

I think #3984 is correctly raising an error, but it is a change in parsing behaviour and will require adjusting some other tests. Previously, a property and an attribute/method with the same name could co-exists in a cdef class. The property would externally shadow the attribut/method, and internally would call the shadowed mangled name, so there was no RecursionError. But this behviour is not really correct. 

The [pure-python test](https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/3984/files#diff-cfbf53318ca35a41eb563e59be5296e1342cfa61d8a3b40f6a065ea279b9166fR1) I added, which segfaults in Cython, shows that Cython does not correctly create the RecursionError that python emits.

> The [pure-python test](https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/3984/files#diff-cfbf53318ca35a41eb563e59be5296e1342cfa61d8a3b40f6a065ea279b9166fR1) I added, which segfaults in Cython, shows that Cython does not correctly create the RecursionError that python emits.

I don't think Cython does anything to detect recursion (so I'd expect a crash rather than a RecursionError). It looks like there's a [new API in Python 3.9](https://docs.python.org/3/c-api/exceptions.html#recursion-control) than could be used to detect recursion. Although it seems like it might be more overhead than is justified for the feature.
Is there a way to assert that a segfault is the intended result of a test or should I remove the test from the PR?

milestone.description:
Goals:
 New version scheme: 3.x instead of 0.x.
 Change default `language_level` from `2` to `3`.
 Change default for `binding` directive from `False` to `True`.
 Fix some Python compatibility issues (if possible, allowing for breaking changes).

title: giacpy fails to build with Cython 3.0
